title: feat(repo): Added api optimizations and improvements

- [x] added pagination validation with limits
- [x] added pagination flattened structure
- [x] moved to very ergonomic traits with defaults - reduced boiler-plate code
- [x] updated db structure references (table columns)

```
  /contracts/{contract_id}/transactions
   /accounts/{address}/transactions
```
due to missing normalized values in the db

title: fix(repo): Add block_timestamp to Block
fix(fuel-streams-subject): Add alias and validate payload conversion
body: This PR ensures the conversion from `SubjectPayload` into `Subject` is valid. Before this an invalid `params: {}` object could be passed in the webserver and nothing was happening, now the validation in happening and we introduce a `subject(alias = "")` to determine which other name a field can have when validating (like serde does)

title: feat(repo): Added blocks rest endpoint
body:
- added blocks endpoint
- added really nice sql statement construction method
- added query deserialization straight into sql query formation

title: fix(repo): Create wrapped int types to fix serialization
body:
This PR fixes an issue we are experiencing when trying to serialize large integers (`u64`) for JSON. We are getting a different final number for types like `receipt.rb` due to JSON limitations.

This issue is likely due to precision loss when handling large integers in JSON serialization/deserialization. In JavaScript/JSON, numbers are represented as IEEE 754 double-precision floating-point numbers, which can only safely represent integers up to 2^53 - 1 (approximately 9 quadrillion) without loss of precision.

- [x] added mock endpoint for getting blocks

title: feat(repo): Add pointers inside the StreamResponse
body:
This PR introduces a fundamental change in how we stream data in our architecture by implementing Record Pointers plus a lot of improvements and reduce of complexity.

## Core Changes
- Introduced Record Pointers to show pointer from the database items in the final stream data 
- Remove overhead over packet creation
- Move historical streaming method to core stream crate
- Remove unnecessary overhead on types and conversions between them
- Move RecordEntity dependent operations to FuelStreams and FuelStores
- Centralize packets conversions from subjects in the domain packets files and reuse in the tests
- Modified store operations:
  - `insert_record` now accepts a database item
  - Store operations now convert packets to database items before insertion

## Additional Changes
- Updated test infrastructure to support the new pointer-based approach
- Enhanced namespace handling across record operations
- Improved consumer service to work with the new pointer system

Example of the new StreamResponse with RecordPointer:

```json
{
    "version": "v1",
    "type": "input",
    "subject": "inputs.coin.height.1234.tx.0x123...index.2",
    "pointer": {
        "block_height": 1234,
        "tx_index": 5,
        "input_index": 2,
        "output_index": null,
        "receipt_index": null
    },
    "payload": {
        ...
    }
}
```

This architectural change provides better type safety and a more efficient way to handle database records while reducing memory overhead in our data systems.

- creates a new web-utils crate which is dynamic and easy to inject in every single microservice
- the latter combines metrics (telemetry), shutdowns, routes, middlewares and exposes them as for direct use
- the crate is then used throughout in all our services exposing metrics and healthchecks

title: fix(publisher): Allow healthcheck while awaiting relayer node sync
fix(publisher): Simplify and test BlocksStream for old and new blocks
body:
BlocksStream now streams old blocks until reaching the latest chain height,
after which it subscribes to new blocks from the fuel-core importer.

This refactor removes the need for the UnpublishedBlocks abstraction, which
previously managed batches of blocks but caused contention issues, starving
fuel-core of its synchronization capacity.

By simplifying the block-handling logic, this fix improves performance, reduces
complexity, and ensures fuel-core can sync effectively.

feat(repo): Fixed nats-url exposure and duplication
body:
The idea of this PR is to achieve consistency of all used nats urls and also mask them to the end-user. This is on the one hand to ensure security by not disclosing an open nats url,  on the other to help the user not having to bother about the url in general, but rather define the fuel-network he cares about. Sam thing has been done on the ts-sdk and it results in a clean design.
Also, we avoid a lot of hardcoded values this way and values re-defined over and over again in the monorepo.

title: feat(repo): Fixed telemetry envs and port
fix(publisher): Resolve block publication race conditions and synchronization issues
body:
## Problem
The current blocks stream publishing mechanism suffers from two critical synchronization challenges:

1. **Receipt Population Failure**: Blocks were not being populated with receipts due to the OffchainDB being out of sync with the OnChainDB.

2. **Block Synchronization Bottleneck**: The existing block import mechanism used a blocking synchronization approach that:
   - Introduced significant latency during block synchronization
   - Risked missing blocks during the import process
   - Blocked the block subscription until all historical blocks were processed

## Solution
This commit introduces the `UnpublishedBlocks` abstraction to resolve these issues:

- Implements a flexible, non-blocking block synchronization strategy
- Ensures blocks are published in sequence based on their heights
- Allows immediate block subscription while synchronizing historical blocks
- Adds a mechanism to wait for OffchainDB to catch up before publishing streams

### Future Improvements
As a potential optimization, when streams are separated into different processes, we can further refine the synchronization strategy to avoid waiting for OffchainDB sync for certain stream types.

References: DS-124

title: ci(repo): General improvements for Cluster structure
body:
## Proof of work 😅 

By just running these commands, you get the cluster running:

```sh
make cluster_setup
make tilt_up
```

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/71682229-d12d-4d45-8c75-833e3bfdf3df)

## Overview
This PR introduces significant changes to the Kubernetes deployment infrastructure and streamlines the publisher service implementation. Here are the key changes:

### 🏗 Infrastructure Changes
1. **Helm Charts Reorganization**
   - Moved charts from `helm/` to `cluster/charts/` directory for better organization
   - Created our own NATS helm chart (`fuel-nats`) to be published to GitHub registry
   - Removed standalone `fuel-surrealdb` chart as it's no longer needed
   - Consolidated publisher and nats chart into `fuel-local` chart for better local development

2. **Scripts Improvements**
   - Added new utility scripts:
     - `build_publisher.sh`: New script for building the publisher Docker image
     - `gen_env_secret.sh`: New script for generating environment secrets
   - Moved all scripts to dedicated `cluster/scripts/` directory
   - Updated Minikube setup script to handle macOS-specific ingress issues

3. **Configuration Updates**
   - Updated `.env.sample` and environment handling
   - Fix environment variable management in `set_envs.sh`
   - Added new configuration for publisher service in local deployment
   - Added GitHub workflow for publishing Helm charts to GitHub registry

### 🧼 Cleanups
   - Removed deprecated k8s-tools Dockerfile
   - Cleaned up unused Helm templates and configurations
   - Removed redundant SurrealDB deployment files
   - Removed old helm directory structure

### 🔧 Development Experience
- Simplified local development setup
- Improved Tiltfile configuration
- Enhanced environment variable management
- Better handling of platform-specific differences (macOS vs others)

## Testing
The changes have been tested in local development environment and ensure:
- Proper publisher service deployment
- Correct transaction processing
- Environment variable handling
- Platform compatibility (macOS support)
- NATS helm chart deployment and configuration

## Migration Notes
1. The SurrealDB deployment should be handled separately if needed
2. Environment variables need to be updated according to new structure
3. Local development setup now uses simplified configuration
4. Charts are now located in `cluster/charts/` instead of `helm/`
5. NATS deployment now uses our own chart from GitHub registry

title: ci(release): Preparing v0.0.13
feat(repo): Introduce FuelStreams Types
body:
Currently, `fuel-core` types are directly exposed to users for streaming. However, this approach has several drawbacks:

1. The serialized structures are tailored for Rust, making them difficult to integrate with existing SDKs.
2. The unstructured serialized output complicates compatibility efforts.
3. Exposing `fuel-core` types could mislead users into assuming related APIs, which require a configured environment, are usable directly with streams.

This PR addresses these issues by introducing `FuelStreams` types, designed as aggregation types optimized for broad use cases. These types are derived from the GraphQL interface used in frontend projects, ensuring a structured and user-friendly format.

Moving forward, we will expand these types to include additional fields based on user needs, making them more versatile and compatible across different integrations.

Closes DS-113

_Subtasks:_
Closes DS-114, DS-115, DS-116, DS-117, DS-118

title: feat(repo): Added local websocket for nats
feat(repo): Added k8s local cluster
refactor(publisher): Remove `PublishError` in favor of `anyhow::Result`
body:
This commit removes PublishError in favor of bubbling pending unactionable errors to `stdout` when there is an error publishing any subject/payload.

Given the focus of the Publish process, only dependent libraries or actionable errors should have an error signature. We can safely do this since it's all application code and we will be relying on our tracing for stack traces to implement certain actions after analyzing the errors. This makes our code more concise for the domain solution it solves.

Closes DS-108

body:
This PR adds:
- max retention time for all entries in nats = 100 blocks (100 * 1 sec)
- skips syncing with blocks whose times are before the last 100.
